name: Acceptable Encryption Policy
content:
Consensus Policy Resource Community
 Acceptable Encryption Policy 
Free Use Disclaimer: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the 
Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. 
There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or 
updated version of this policy, please send email to policy-resources@sans.org. 
Last Update Status: Updated June 2014 
1. Overview 
See Purpose. 
2. Purpose 
The purpose of this policy is to provide guidance that limits the use of encryption to those 
algorithms that have received substantial public review and have been proven to work 
effectively. Additionally, this policy provides direction to ensure that Federal regulations are 
followed, and legal authority is granted for the dissemination and use of encryption technologies 
outside of the United States. 
3. Scope 
This policy applies to all <Company Name> employees and affiliates. 
4. Policy 
4.1 Algorithm Requirements 
4.1.1 Ciphers in use must meet or exceed the set defined as "AES-compatible" or 
"partially AES-compatible" according to the IETF/IRTF Cipher Catalog, or the 
set defined for use in the United States National Institute of Standards and 
Technology (NIST) publication FIPS 140-2, or any superseding documents 
according to the date of implementation. The use of the Advanced Encryption 
Standard (AES) is strongly recommended for symmetric encryption. 
4.1.2 Algorithms in use must meet the standards defined for use in NIST publication 
FIPS 140-2 or any superseding document, according to date of implementation. 
The use of the RSA and Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) algorithms is 
strongly recommended for asymmetric encryption. 
4.1.3 Signature Algorithms

4.2 Hash Function Requirements 
In general, <Company Name> adheres to the NIST Policy on Hash Functions.  
4.3 Key Agreement and Authentication 
4.3.1 Key exchanges must use one of the following cryptographic protocols: Diffie
Hellman, IKE, or Elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH). 
4.3.2 End points must be authenticated prior to the exchange or derivation of session 
keys. 
4.3.3 Public keys used to establish trust must be authenticated prior to use.  Examples 
of authentication include transmission via cryptographically signed message or 
manual verification of the public key hash. 
4.3.4 All servers used for authentication (for example, RADIUS or TACACS) must 
have installed a valid certificate signed by a known trusted provider. 
4.3.5 All servers and applications using SSL or TLS must have the certificates signed 
by a known, trusted provider.  
4.4 Key Generation 
4.4.1 Cryptographic keys must be generated and stored in a secure manner that prevents 
loss, theft, or compromise.  
4.4.2 Key generation must be seeded from an industry standard random number 
generator (RNG). For examples, see NIST Annex C: Approved Random Number 
Generators for FIPS PUB 140-2.   
5. Policy Compliance 
5.1 Compliance Measurement 
The Infosec team will verify compliance to this policy through various methods, including but 
not limited to, business tool reports, internal and external audits, and feedback to the policy 
owner.  
5.2 Exceptions 
Any exception to the policy must be approved by the Infosec team in advance.  
5.3 Non-Compliance 
An employee found to have violated this policy may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and 
including termination of employment.  
6 Related Standards, Policies and Processes 
National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publication FIPS 140-2, 
NIST Policy on Hash Functions 
7 Definitions and Terms 
The following definition and terms can be found in the SANS Glossary located at:

name: Acceptable Use Policy
content:
As an IT policy expert and corporate writer, here is a comprehensive and professionally formatted "Acceptable Use Policy" document ready for corporate use.

---

# Acceptable Use Policy

| **Policy Name:**      | Acceptable Use Policy                                |
| :-------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------- |
| **Policy ID:**        | CORP-IT-SEC-001                                      |
| **Version:**          | 1.0                                                  |
| **Effective Date:**   | 2023-10-27                                           |
| **Review Date:**      | 2024-10-27                                           |

---

## 1. Purpose

The purpose of this Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) is to outline the acceptable and ethical use of [Company Name]'s information technology (IT) resources. This policy ensures the security, integrity, and availability of our IT systems and data, protects company assets, complies with legal and regulatory requirements, and promotes a productive, professional, and respectful work environment for all users.

## 2. Scope

This policy applies to all employees, contractors, temporary staff, interns, consultants, and any third-party individuals or entities granted access to [Company Name]'s IT resources (collectively, "Users").

It covers all company-owned, leased, or managed IT resources, including but not limited to:
*   Networks (wired and wireless)
*   Servers, workstations, laptops, and other computing devices
*   Software, applications, and operating systems
*   Data, files, and databases
*   Internet services, intranet, and cloud services
*   Email, instant messaging, and other communication tools
*   Mobile devices (company-issued or personal devices used for business purposes)
*   Telecommunication services

This policy applies regardless of the physical location (on-site or remote) or the device used to access these resources.

## 3. Policy Statements

### 3.1 General Principles

All Users are expected to exercise good judgment and common sense in their use of [Company Name]'s IT resources. Use of these resources must be:
*   Consistent with applicable laws and regulations.
*   In line with [Company Name]'s ethical standards and values.
*   Primarily for business-related purposes.
*   Respectful of others and free from harassment or discrimination.

### 3.2 Authorized and Prohibited Use

#### 3.2.1 Authorized Use
*   IT resources are provided primarily to facilitate the User's job duties and company business.
*   Limited and occasional personal use is permissible, provided it does not interfere with job performance, consume excessive resources, violate any other company policies, or incur significant cost to [Company Name].

#### 3.2.2 Prohibited Activities
The following activities are strictly prohibited when using [Company Name]'s IT resources:

*   **Illegal Activities**: Engaging in or promoting any activity that is illegal under applicable local, national, or international laws.
*   **Harassment or Offensive Content**: Creating, storing, transmitting, or displaying any content that is discriminatory, harassing, defamatory, sexually explicit, obscene, or otherwise offensive, hateful, or inappropriate.
*   **Unauthorized Access**: Attempting to gain unauthorized access to any system, network, or data, or circumventing security controls, without explicit written permission from the IT Department. This includes "hacking" or attempting to exploit vulnerabilities.
*   **Malware Distribution**: Introducing, installing, or distributing malware, viruses, worms, Trojan horses, ransomware, or other malicious code onto any IT resource.
*   **Intellectual Property Infringement**: Downloading, copying, sharing, or distributing copyrighted material (e.g., software, music, videos, documents) without proper authorization, licensing, or legal right.
*   **Excessive Personal Use**: Engaging in personal use that significantly impacts job performance, consumes excessive network bandwidth or storage, or incurs significant cost to the company.
*   **Resource Abuse**: Deliberately consuming excessive network bandwidth, storage, processing power, or otherwise disrupting the availability or performance of IT resources.
*   **Political Lobbying/Activism**: Using company IT resources for personal political lobbying, activism, or for the support of any non-company-approved external organizations.
*   **Chain Letters/Spam**: Sending unsolicited mass emails ("spam") or participating in chain letters, pyramid schemes, or similar activities.
*   **Gambling**: Accessing or engaging in online gambling.

### 3.3 Data Handling and Confidentiality

*   Users must handle company data in accordance with the [Company Name] Data Classification Policy and Data Privacy Policy.
*   Confidential, proprietary, and sensitive data must be protected from unauthorized access, modification, or disclosure at all times.
*   Company data must not be stored on personal devices or unapproved cloud services without explicit authorization and appropriate security measures.
*   All data created or stored on company IT resources is the property of [Company Name].

### 3.4 Security Responsibilities

*   **Password Management**: Users are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality and integrity of their passwords and access credentials. Passwords must never be shared and must meet [Company Name]'s complexity requirements.
*   **Device Protection**: Users are responsible for taking reasonable steps to protect company-issued devices (e.g., laptops, mobile phones) from loss, theft, and damage. Devices must be secured with passwords/PINs and encryption where required.
*   **Reporting Incidents**: Any suspected security incidents, policy violations, system vulnerabilities, or unusual activity must be immediately reported to the IT Department.
*   **Physical Security**: Ensure company devices and data are physically secure, especially when working in public spaces or unattended.
*   **Remote Access**: Remote access to company networks must always be conducted using approved secure methods (e.g., VPN) and comply with all security protocols.

### 3.5 Internet and Email Usage

*   **Professional Conduct**: All internet and email communications must be professional and reflect positively on [Company Name].
*   **Email for Business**: Company email accounts are primarily for business communication. Limited personal use is permissible if it does not violate any other policy, interfere with work, or create liability for the company.
*   **No Illegal Downloads**: Do not download or distribute illegal or unauthorized content via the internet or email.
*   **External Communications**: Users must exercise caution when clicking on links or opening attachments from unknown or suspicious sources.

### 3.6 Software and Licensing

*   Only authorized and properly licensed software may be installed on company-owned devices.
*   Users must not install personal software on company devices without explicit approval from the IT Department.
*   All software must be used in compliance with its licensing agreements.

### 3.7 Mobile Devices

*   Users accessing company resources via personal mobile devices (Bring Your Own Device - BYOD) must adhere to the [Company Name] Mobile Device Policy and ensure adequate security measures are in place as required by the company.
*   Company-issued mobile devices must be used in accordance with this policy and the Mobile Device Policy.

### 3.8 Privacy and Monitoring

*   Users should have no expectation of privacy regarding their use of [Company Name]'s IT resources.
*   [Company Name] reserves the right to monitor, log, and review all activity on its IT systems, networks, and data, including internet usage, email communications, instant messages, and file content, for security, operational, compliance, and investigative purposes, as permitted by law. This monitoring may occur without prior notice.

## 4. Roles and Responsibilities

*   **All Users**:
    *   Read, understand, and comply with this policy and all related IT policies.
    *   Use company IT resources responsibly, ethically, and lawfully.
    *   Report any suspected policy violations, security incidents, or vulnerabilities to the IT Department immediately.
    *   Protect company information and IT assets from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction.
*   **Management/Supervisors**:
    *   Ensure their direct reports understand and adhere to this policy.
    *   Address any known or suspected policy violations within their teams and report them to IT and HR.
    *   Support the IT Department in enforcing this policy.
*   **IT Department**:
    *   Develop, maintain, and update this policy.
    *   Implement and manage the IT infrastructure and security controls necessary to support this policy.
    *   Provide guidance and training to Users on acceptable use practices.
    *   Monitor IT resources for compliance and investigate suspected violations.
    *   Report policy violations to appropriate management and Human Resources.
*   **Human Resources Department**:
    *   Consult with management and the IT Department on policy enforcement and disciplinary actions.
    *   Ensure that disciplinary actions are consistent and compliant with company policy and labor laws.

## 5. Enforcement

Any violation of this Acceptable Use Policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract, and may also include legal action, civil penalties, and restitution for any damages incurred by [Company Name]. [Company Name] reserves the right to suspend or revoke IT system access immediately for actual or suspected policy violations without prior notice.

## 6. Related Documents

*   Information Security Policy
*   Data Classification Policy
*   Data Privacy Policy
*   Mobile Device Policy
*   Remote Work Policy
*   Incident Response Policy
*   [Company Name] Code of Conduct
